Award.AwardTitle: The effect of nameability on categorization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Humans have remarkable abilities to find deep similarities in what are superficially different experiences and to use those similarities to help categorize their experiences. This process of categorization allows people to learn from examples and to generalize that knowledge to new situations. Categorization is also a fundamental aspect of human reasoning. This work investigates whether a key contributor to human categorization success is the ability to name the features and dimensions that compose the categories. Testing the causal link between naming and categorizing helps us understand why children with poorer language skills often go on to have poor academic outcomes, even in domains that appear to be nonverbal in nature like geometry. This work enhances scientific infrastructure by developing a freely available online tool for measuring the nameability of any visual or auditory set of items for adults and children, which will help researchers and educators more effectively describe learning strategies and allow for better understanding the sources of children's reasoning errors.

To explain what makes some categories harder to learn than others, researchers have typically posited a fixed set of features that are available to the learner. But where do the features come from? This work tests the hypothesis that an important source of features is the words people learn when learning a language. On this view, the words of a language do not simply map onto pre-existing conceptual distinctions, but are one of the contributing factors that create the distinctions. This hypothesis is tested using a series of category-learning and category-induction experiments with adults and a unique population of linguistically deprived children. The experiments systematically test the extent to which ease of naming predicts categorization success and tests the causal involvement of language by using verbal interference protocols. The behavioral work is guided by computational modeling using convolutional neural networks to help disentangle whether a category is easy to learn because it is nameable or whether it is nameable because it is easy to learn. This work is among the first to use deep-learning models to understand human categorization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At the root of cognition is categorization -- a process through which we represent different things -- objects, actions, diseases, abstract entities --  as being in some ways the same. Although all animals form categories, humans have an unparalleled ability to learn and deploy categories in a highly flexible and context-sensitive way. Among the abilities supported by categorization is recognizing a new item as a member of a previously learned category, and making categorically-informed inferences: because it is a member of category X, it likely has properties that other members of category X have.

Some categories are harder to learn than others. But what makes them hard? Previous work has tended to focus on properties intrinsic to the categories such as their structure and perceptual properties. For example, categories whose members are very perceptually similar are unsurprisingly harder to learn than categories that are more perceptually distinct. In this project we focused on a very different aspect of categories -- their nameability -- and sought to answer the question of whether a key contributor to human categorization success is the ability to name the dimensions and features that compose categories.

As we learn a language, we learn its core vocabulary. Although it is tempting to think that the words of our language just pick out categories that we have already learned, there is converging evidence that the words of our language guide us to learn some categories over others. As part of this project, we conducted a series of behavioral experiments showing categories with more nameble constituent parts are easier to learn than categories with less nameable constituents even when their perceptul factors and logical structure are equated. This result suggested that reasoning tests that are used as part of nearly every IQ test to measure nonverbal fluid reasoning may depend on language after all. Controlling for their logical complexity, fluid reasoning problems with easier to name parts were easier for people to solve. In other work, we found that the relationship between naming and categorization is likely to be a causal one because speakers of different languages perform differently on categorization tasks in a way that is predicted by differences in nameability and that because interfering with language selectively affects categorization of ordinarily easy-to-name relations.

Understanding the causal link between naming and category learning is important not only for better understanding how human categorization works, but also for answering more applied questions. Over the last decade developmental psychologists have become acutely aware of the strong links between early language experience and cognitive outcomes.  Among the work funded by this project has been a series of studies examining how the types of words children know at a young age predict the words they go on to learn and their performance on "nonverbal" categorization tasks. Among other broader impacts of our work has been to extend tools developed by machine learning researchers (convolutional neural networks) to helping us understand how exposure to different kinds of verbal labels impact the representations formed by these neural netwroks, helping establish them as a model system that we can use to study effects of language on categorization in a more controlled way than what is possible with human subjects.
